text: hi everyone
Anthony Fantana here the Internet's
busiest music nerd and it's time for a
review this town needs guns or most
recently shortened to TT and g13 point
zero point zero zero zero obviously the
title and the cover from this album are
a reference to the Mayan calendar and
the sort of shift we've made into a new
era according to this calendar and you
know we were all freaked out about the
world's can end
[Music]
these guys are a rock outfit hailing
from the UK this is their sophomore
full-length LP and one of math rocks
more emotional and indie rock flavored
bands an also a group that has had quite
a bit of turbulence over the course of
their musical career over the years the
band has gone through at least half a
dozen different members some of them
even leaving the group before they were
actually able to put out their first
full-length LP and with this new LP this
town needs guns or TT and G is actually
premiering a new singer Henry
Tremaine and even though all this change
has kind of gone on with the band's
ranks it hasn't really affected focus or
progression I guess you could say
because right now the group is kind of
with with this LP settled into this
combination of song structures written
with that straightforward modern
accessible indie rock Sensibility along
with a lot of math rock guitar phrasing
and drumming and there is a bit of emo
influence on the side with many of the
songs on this LP as well which really
really influenced not only the melody
writing but sort of the personality of
the vocals as well there might also be a
bit of a sort of slick mainstream
alternative rock vibe going on with some
of the tracks here as well there is
definitely an avoidance of aggression
and abrasion on this LP which really
does kind of turn some people off too
many underground rock bands the only
sort of modern groups that I could think
to instantly compare these guys to are
bands like I guess sort of maps and
allyce's which also combine elements of
math rock with indie rock however I
don't really find maps and atlases
songwriting to be all that kind of sharp
or or memorable I could compare these
guys to a group maybe like - the Bears
well although I've never really been a
huge - the bear fan either in my opinion
what can be so enjoyable about TT ng on
this LP is that they're enjoyability
comes pretty easy despite a pretty
obvious technical
bleurgh the difficult to execute guitar
work is here on many songs on this album
but it doesn't really impede the emotion
of the track right from the start of
this LP with the song cat fantastic this
town needs guns brings with Henry charm
Ian's vocals
this very sort of lazily whimper a slow
singing vocal that even though I kind of
use those adjectives they're not really
fantastic adjectives it's sort of a
captivating singing voice the vocals
really have kind of a sweet modern
melody to them especially when the band
breaks into this slow down area of the
track where all these guitar arpeggios
hit and it feels like the chords are
descending but yet ascending really
quickly it's an awesome just top-notch
stellar chord progression on this part
of the track the time signature is kind
of off kilter the segues in between the
portions of this track are great the
grooves are nice this track is well
executed it's loaded with musical
details I actually have kind of a
strange attraction to a lot of the vocal
melodies on this LP I don't exactly
think Henry is maybe as weird or maybe
as I guess sort of standout a vocalist
as TTM geez last singer but he is a
smoother singer I do think he has kind
of a wider appeal with his voice Henry
has a tendency to sing at a much slower
pace than these sort of very busy and
complex guitars and drums kind of
hacking away at all these interesting
ideas underneath him and it kind of
gives the listener the opportunity to
listen to the song at two different
paces it's sort of like the vocals and
the the guitars and drums are sort of in
their own little worlds and yet they are
so tight and they are so together and
they complement each other so well a lot
of the songs on the first half of this
LP are pretty good I don't think the
album falters until the band starts
introducing these kind of short
interlude segue tracks that are too
short to really kind of leave an impact
of their own and yet don't really bring
the album into any new phases or
sections or anything like that
after these segue tracks
are basically tracks that sound like the
tracks you heard before the Segway
tracks I'm not sure if TT mg is trying
to distract away from that by throwing
in these short little bits that are
either acoustic or maybe have a little
bit of piano or kind of have an
electronic beat in them to kind of make
it feel like there's some sort of
diversity but the album doesn't really
change gears in any significant way
until the track two birds one stone
which is an acoustic song and a
beautifully awesome one but the track
isn't really all that well developed
when compared to other songs here and
the song honest-to-god spends an entire
minute fading out the rest of the LP is
pretty nice it doesn't really actually
kind of grab my attention in any
significant way until the track plus
three awesomeness repels water on which
the band is actually jamming really hard
on a pretty nice groove I love the way
that these guys can just intricately
layer guitars and drums and with just so
little instrumentation just makes so
much sound and just keep it kind of
sweet keep it enjoyable and just
intoxicatingly
relaxing which I think in a nutshell
kind of describes this LP I'm feeling a
strong six to a life seven on this LP if
you've given it a listen what did you
think of it love it hate it why and what
do you think I should review next
anthony Fantana this town needs guns
dirty T and G forever
